bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed and Blossom Reed, November 2, 1951

div1.p: Hench informs Lawrence and Blossom Reed that he is receiving numerous requests for his Reed materials. He notes that he would like to develop a policy regarding photographs and proper credit; in this matter he requests Lawrence Reed's opinion.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed and Blossom Reed, November 2, 1951
div1.opener:
November 2, 1951
General Walter Lawrence Reed
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Dear Friends:
div1.p:
As custodian of the extremely interesting and valuable material concerning
your father, I feel a great responsibility and I feel obligated to be as
helpful as possible to the growing number of people who write me for in-
formation. I have also received a number of requests recently for copies
of photographs - requests from the Army people, from Walter Reed Hospital,
from certain newspapers and magazines. I consider it my duty to grant
whatever requests seem dignified and in good taste. I have granted a
number of such requests in recent months, and indeed I have spent many
hours recently helping two or three writers but this I am delighted to do.

When your mother was living you may remember that I made copies of several
photographs of your father for such affairs as the program of the unveiling
of the Walter Reed statue in the Hall of Fame in New York. I was asked to
give them a credit line for the photographs. Under some of them I sug-
gested they put the name “Mrs. Walter Reed,” under one or two I think the
credit line read “Mrs. Walter Reed and Dr. P. S. Hench.”

At present I am sending to Dr. W. Edwin Hemphill, History Division, Virginia
State Library, Richmond, Virginia, three or four pictures (one of your
father's medical diploma from the University of Virginia) for publication
in an article which will appear shortly in the VIRGINIA CAVALCADE. I
should like to develop a policy regarding the credit line. Would you
like me to put under these photographs “The Reed Family”? This I should
be delighted to do. On the other hand, I don't want numerous people
bothering you, writing letters to you, unless you would like to hear from
those who are writing articles, etc. I do not like to use just my name as
a credit line but I do think it is best to have the magazines use a credit
line so that perhaps some control over the use of the photographs can be
made. In other words, I do not think that the editors of the VIRGINIA
CAVALCADE would pass on to others the photographs which I am now sending
them unless they had definite authority to do so, whereas if no credit
line were given they might consider themselves at liberty to use the
photographs in any way they or others might wish. Another way might be
to use some such line as “The Reed Family and Dr. P. S. Hench” or “The
Reed Family through Dr. P. S. Hench.”

I would appreciate it greatly if you would let me know what you would
like to have me do in this matter. I enclose a stamped, addressed
air mail envelope for reply.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
